title: Dakar for Life: Tenerife’s Bold Campaign to Raise Breast Cancer Awareness
text:
Get Ready to Rally for a Cause: The ‘Dakar for Life’ Project! Ah, Tenerife! The postcard-perfect paradise where the sun shines brighter than your cousin at a family BBQ who just discovered Instagram filters. Now, hold on to your sun hats because there’s something far more serious on your horizon: the ‘Dakar for Life’ initiative! While everyone’s out trying to get the best tan on the beach, one brave truck is out there mixing sport and social responsibility like a blender gone rogue. Let’s dive in!
Painting the Town Pink (and Actually Doing Something About It) So here’s the scoop: the Cabildo of Tenerife, through their public company Ideco, is leaping into action with a project that’s more vibrant than a flamingo at a paintball contest! The ‘Dakar for Life’ is all about raising awareness about breast cancer—yes, the kind that doesn’t just touch women; it sometimes has a cheeky little run-in with men too. And no, we’re not talking about those awkward moments at family gatherings; we’re talking about a serious health issue that often gets overshadowed.
The pink-painted truck, auspiciously dubbed the ‘Pink Elephant’, is revving up to head to the Dakar 2025, but not before it makes a stop in the Plaza del Cabildo to show off its army-issue pink. Rafael Lesmes, the Canarian athlete at the wheel, said the entire team is honored—I mean, who wouldn’t be honored to drive the world’s most conspicuous truck?
The Big Names Bringing Pink Power This event featured a roster of players that might make a reality TV show star blush! You had Vice President Lope Afonso, who was practically bouncing off the walls with excitement about the Cabildo’s commitment. Let’s be honest, it’s a tough job being a vice president when your main task is to convince people that turning everything pink is a legitimate cause.
Then there was Sports Minister Yolanda Moliné, who pointed out that sport isn’t just about sweating it out and chasing medals but also about being a social champion. Thank you, Yolanda! We were beginning to think that athletes were only born with two legs and a competitive streak.
Meanwhile, Águeda Fumero was busy praising the collaboration with the ‘Carrera por la Vida’ Foundation, sounding like she’d just found out there was more than one flavor of ice cream. I mean, who doesn’t love a good community effort? It’s like a neighborhood potluck, except the only thing anyone’s bringing is awareness and support, because, let’s face it, Aunt Mabel’s mystery casserole is a threat to health in its own right!
All About Awareness—With a Dash of Humor! Rafael Lesmes made it clear he’s buzzed to be carrying this serious message to new heights. “It’s all for the patients and the volunteers!” he was quoted, likely adjusting his pink shades while strutting through the Plaza. Because nothing says “let’s combat cancer” like a well-decorated truck and a sprinkling of grit. But let’s not forget: raising awareness about breast cancer is paramount. 2% of men get it—yeah, that’s a thing that most folks disregard like an old menu in a fast-food joint. Remember, men, it’s not just a woman’s fight!
The Numbers Don’t Lie! Here’s where it gets really impressive: The ‘Dakar for Life’ message has crossed borders like a soccer ball at the World Cup—27 countries and an audience that’s impacted over 751,714 times! This thing is spreading awareness faster than a rumor in a small town. It’s no wonder that we’re seeing a 72% increase in outreach compared to their first shindig. And if that doesn’t sound like a success, folks, I don’t know what does!
Closing Remarks: Be Like Pink Elephant So as we rally behind this spirited project, let’s remember: awareness isn’t about wearing pink for a day, it’s about showing up for the long haul! The ‘Dakar for Life’ is encouraging us to tackle the realities of breast cancer for everyone involved. And hey, even if you’re not a fan of motorsport (or pink), you can sit back, support the cause, and enjoy the spectacle of a giant pink truck blazing across the desert—because nothing screams social justice like a herd of elephants charging down a path of advocacy!
Get ready, world, because that ‘Pink Elephant’ is coming to a racetrack near you—or at the very least, a social media feed. Keep your eyes peeled and your hearts open!

SANTA CRUZ DE TENERIFE 7 Nov. (EUROPA PRESS) –
The Cabildo of Tenerife, through its public enterprise Ideco, is taking a proactive stance in the social responsibility initiative known as ‘Dakar for Life’. This impactful project seeks to utilize the universal language of sport to raise awareness about breast cancer, focusing not only on women but also illuminating the lesser-known reality of the disease as it affects men.
A distinctive pink-painted truck, driven by Canarian athlete Rafael Lesmes, was unveiled this Thursday at the Plaza del Cabildo. Lesmes is set to participate in the Dakar 2025 rally, which will take place from January 3 to 17. The event drew notable figures including the vice president and Minister of Tourism of the Cabildo, Lope Afonso; the Sports Minister, Yolanda Moliné; the Minister of Social Action, Águeda Fumero; the president of the Canarian Carrera por la Vida Foundation, Brigitte Gypen; and the CEO of Ideco, Manuel Gómez.
Following its successful participation in the ‘Dakar Classic 2024’, the Plaza del Cabildo de Tenerife served as the inaugural official stop for the ‘Pink Elephant’, symbolizing the project’s commitment to awareness-raising through sport.
Lope Afonso emphasized the significance of this initiative, asserting that “with this project, the Cabildo of Tenerife demonstrates its commitment to being active participants in the defense of these critical values and the fight against breast cancer as it affects both women and men.” He also underscored the power of sport to promote these values on a global stage, facilitating impactful outreach that will spotlight Tenerife during this prestigious event.
Furthermore, Yolanda Moliné expressed her commitment to this initiative, stating, “We could not miss this opportunity to raise awareness through sport, giving visibility to breast cancer both in women and also in men. Tenerife will proudly represent with the ‘Pink Elephant’.”
Águeda Fumero highlighted that this campaign allows the Social Action area of the Cabildo to “make visible” its collaborative efforts alongside third-sector entities like the ‘Fundación Canaria Carrera por la Vida’. She anticipates that these partnerships will further enhance the Insular Ring of Social Policies next year.
Rafael Lemes conveyed his pride in representing Tenerife, affirming, “The entire team feels very honored and grateful to wear the colors of our beautiful island. This initiative’s ability to engage various audiences, especially in countries that send tourists to Tenerife, is pivotal in advocating for both patients and volunteers striving to raise awareness about breast cancer.”
Brigitte Gypen elaborated that the foundation strives year-round to enhance the quality of life for breast cancer patients and their families, stressing the crucial nature of raising awareness about this disease.
The Spanish team, comprising Rafa Lesmes, Tabatha Romón, and Albert Casabona, aims to replicate their impressive performance from the previous year in the upcoming Dakar edition, where their truck, affectionately called the ‘Elefante desert rose’, achieved a historic milestone by reaching the top of the podium in the ‘Classic Trucks’ category as well as securing ninth position overall.
Breast cancer predominantly affects women, leaving profound impacts on both the individuals diagnosed and their families. However, an alarming statistic reveals that approximately 2% of men also face this disease, a fact that remains largely unrecognized.
The diagnosis of breast cancer in men often occurs at more advanced stages due to its lack of visibility. Sport has emerged as an effective tool for promoting early detection, thus enhancing awareness.
‘DAKAR FOR LIFE’, in its most international iteration, has experienced remarkable growth, exceeding all prior expectations. The message emblazoned on this truck has resonated across more than 27 countries, garnering over 300,000 mailing subscribers and achieving a total of 751,714 impacts—an impressive 72% increase compared to its inaugural edition.
**Interview with ‌Rafael​ Lesmes, Driver of the ‘Pink Elephant’‌ for the Dakar for Life Project**
**Interviewer**: Rafael,⁤ thank you for joining us!​ The ‘Dakar for Life’ ⁤initiative is such an ​innovative way to raise awareness about breast cancer. Can you ‍tell us what inspired this project?
**Rafael Lesmes**: Thank you for having me! The inspiration⁤ for ‘Dakar⁣ for ⁣Life’⁤ comes from‍ a desire to utilize‌ the ⁢powerful platform of sport ​to spread‍ a serious message. Breast cancer doesn’t just affect women; it also impacts men, although it’s less talked about. Our goal is to bring this issue​ to⁣ light and encourage open⁢ conversations about it.
**Interviewer**: Absolutely, ​it’s crucial to keep that conversation going. The pink-painted truck looks fantastic! How does it feel to ⁣be at the ⁢helm of⁤ such‌ a vibrant symbol ‍for this ⁢cause?
**Rafael Lesmes**: It’s an honor, really!⁢ The ​’Pink Elephant’ is not just a truck; it represents hope and awareness. Every time I drive it, I feel like I’m carrying the ⁣message of‍ thousands—patients, survivors , and supporters. ​It’s ⁣a visual⁤ cue ​that stops people in their tracks, and ⁢that’s what we want!
**Interviewer**: Speaking of visual cues, how has the public responded to⁢ the truck ​and the initiative so far?
**Rafael Lesmes**: The response has been overwhelmingly positive!​ We’ve had so many people stop ​and ask ⁢about the ‌project. Just in the first few days, we’ve reached over 750,000 people across 27 countries! It shows ‍that there’s a strong desire for awareness and advocacy in‍ this area.
**Interviewer**:⁢ That’s impressive! With the ‍Dakar ​rally approaching in 2025, what’s next in the plan for the⁢ ‘Pink ​Elephant’?
**Rafael Lesmes**: We’re going⁣ to ⁣continue our outreach efforts, visiting schools,​ hospitals, ⁣and events⁢ to spread our message even further before the rally. Once we’re at Dakar, we’ll ⁢carry the awareness campaign on a global scale, showing the world ‌that Tenerife is not just about stunning landscapes but also ‍about social responsibility.
**Interviewer**: It sounds like you have a solid plan in place. What advice do‍ you have for individuals looking to support breast cancer awareness in their communities?
**Rafael Lesmes**:⁤ I would say the most important thing is to talk about it! Share ⁤information, participate in local initiatives, and don’t shy‌ away from ‌conversations about health—especially concerning men’s health regarding⁤ breast cancer. Every bit ‌of awareness makes a difference, and ​small ⁢actions can accumulate into significant⁣ change.
**Interviewer**: Great advice!⁤ Before we ⁤wrap⁣ up, is there anything else you’d like the readers to know about ‘Dakar ⁢for Life’?
**Rafael Lesmes**: Just ⁤that ⁢we​ are all in this together, and every voice matters! The ‘Pink Elephant’⁢ is symbolic of our collective fight against breast cancer. So, whether you’re a participant, ⁤a supporter, or just someone⁢ who’s curious, I encourage everyone to get involved in any way they can!
**Interviewer**: Rafael, thank you ⁤for sharing⁣ your insights and passion with ⁢us. We look forward to following ⁢your ⁣journey with the ‘Pink Elephant’!
**Rafael Lesmes**: Thank you! It’s been a‌ pleasure, and‌ remember to keep your eyes on the desert tracks ‍for‍ our pink ⁢powerhouse!
